0:46 I would like to point out that the fact that an electron can actually be present inside the nucleus of an atom is wrong, thanks to the Uncertainty Principle. The Uncertainty Principle places a non-zero , lower bound on the product of the uncertainties in the position and the momentum of a particle, or, in other words, prevents us from knowing exactly the position and the momentum of the particle at the same time. Mathematically, it can be expressed as Δx.Δp≥h/4π. Let us assume that the electron is present in the nucleus. Let the diameter of the nucleus be d, the mass of the electron be m, and the uncertainty in its velocity be Δv.
Now, since the electron is inside the nucleus, the maximum uncertainty in its position would be the diameter of the nucleus. Hence Δx=d.Also, Δp=mΔv. Plugging these values in the Uncertainty Principle,
Δx.Δp≥h/4π
d.mΔv≥h/4π
Δv≥h/(4πd.m)
Now, d lies between (10^-15)m and (10^-14)m. For Δv to be minimum, choose d=(10^-14)m. Putting in the values of the constants in the above equation, we get:
Δv≥(6.626e-34)/(4*3.14*1e-14*9.1e-31)=5.77e9 m/s.
Hence for an electron to be inside the nucleus, the minimum uncertainty in its velocity, and hence its minimum velocity would have to be 5.77e9 m/s, which is not possible since it is much greater than the cosmic speed limit, the speed of light(≈ 3e8m/s). Hence the electron cannot be inside the nucleus. Q.E.D.

This is the worst explanation of quantum tunneling I have ever heard. A ball rolling down a mountain? Are you joking? QT cannot be compared to a ball of matter rolling downhill.

Quantum tunneling occurs when energy is fired at a barrier, usually a lead wall at a defined thickness. And every so often the energy can be measured on the other side of the barrier. The distance from the electron producing device to the detector is known. The speed of light is also known so physicists are able to calculate the speed of the energy. They discovered that the energy does not slow down when it passes through the barrier. Instead it passes through the barrier like the barrier is not there. Meaning the energy instantly passes through the barrier and continues on it's journey. This is quantum tunneling. Energy passing through a barrier as if the barrier was not there. This has nothing to do with balls of matter.

I surmise, because of wave particle duality of light, the single particle that is fired out the device is not truly a particle but an energy wave of potential particles, plural! When the energy wave strikes the barrier, because it is a wave like sound, every so often, will reverberate instantly being transferred to the other side. That wave then continues on until it is measured. The moment the wave is measured is when it becomes a particle. In reality the particle doesn't even travel through the barrier at all, it was the wave.

Quantum tunneling of energy has nothing to do with balls of matter rolling down a mountain.

It's like with indoor noise when a sound wave hits a wall. Most of the wave bounces back but some of it gets through and can be faintly heard outside. In quantum physics all particles are said to also be waves because they exhibit many of the same behaviors. They always act like particles when measured but until they are measured they are theoretically in every possible location along the wave. If any of the wave gets through an object and then the "particle" is measured it could be on the part of the wave that made it through the object. It could even be on the part of the wave that is passing through the object. Of course this is just a very crude analogy, if you want to know more about how it actually works I suggest searching for "quantum tunneling" on wikipedia. Quantum tunneling is behavior by matter that is "allowed" by quantum mechanics, but highly improbable. The most probable place for any particle to be is very near the position one would expect from classical physics. But when dealing with the nearly infinite number of particles that make up matter, the chances become good that a small portion will do improbable things. Radioactivity is an example of this phenomenon. Particles jumping through a barrier that should have stopped them is another.

Quantum tunneling is a quirk of quantum mechanics that arises from the uncertainty principle.  Essentially, the position of a quantum mechanical object is probablistic.  Imagine if a tennis ball was a QM object and you sent it off in the direction of a wall, probablistically, when you observed the ball, it is more likely that it would be on this side of the wall.  But, it COULD be on the other side.  This magic leap is quantum tunneling, objects "passing through other solid objects".

Short answer - it wont hang around for long.  Most likely is that it would be emmited from the nucleus, however it could also interact with the protons and in some very rare situations with the neutrons.  In almost all proton electron interactions of this type the electron would be "captured" (look up K-capture) in which case the proton would turn to a neutron, the atom would change element as it now has one less proton, and the nucleus would emit a neutrino (the remnant of the electron).

For those who don't understand:

The valley and the mountain are metaphors for the energy barrier needed to perform chemical reactions. Basically, every chemical reaction needs a certain amount of energy (usually heat) to be added into the system (what contains the reaction) in order for the reaction to occur. When we talk about reactions "giving off" or "absorbing" energy, we are talking about the net, or total, amount of energy exchanged in the system.

Not true. The simplest beta decay reaction is:
Neutron --->  Proton + Electron + antineutrino
This implies that
Antineutrino + Electron + Proton --> Neutron
Which implies that
Electron + Proton --> Neutron + Neutrino
This process does not break any laws and happens inside neutron stars. However the energy/pressure on an electron must be extraordinarily large (beta particles are expelled with a lot of energy) to cause this reaction and will not occur under anything close to normal.

Quantum tunneling is already heavily used. LASERs have a mostly silvered mirror on.one end and a fully silvered mirror on the other. The light emitted from a laser has to tunnel out of the softer mirror. One way mirrors at a police station also quantum tunnel light. Flash memory in nearly every handheld electronic device uses tunneling in the info storage process. CCD cameras and electron microscopes also use tunneling. There are even more examples but I ran out of space to write them!

@wilmington2015 Only on the quantum scale. As he said, quantum mechanics is probabilistic. Electrons have a small chance of, like, being anywhere.

@deppwaswho The position of every particle is described by a wavefunction that is a solution to Schrodingers equation.  The reason the particle can "teleport" is because, if the particle has enough energy and/or the barrier is weak enough, the solution's value is functionally non-zero, even on the other side of the barrier.  Logically, if the wavefunction is non-zero on the other side of the barrier, it is non-zero INSIDE the barrier as well.

@MichaelChin1994 Plenty of rules of reality apply - just not the intuitive ones of classical mechanics.  And no, anything cannot happen -- QM puts some very definite constraints on the nature of reality.

@gawdzila Oh, I see. :O

You know, it's surprising how much of that I actually understand, not being a Physicist myself. :D

@DeadSOLz
A real ball wouldn't.  But if it was an electron, and instead of a mountain between valleys it was an insulator between two conductors, then it could.  The real answer for why it happens is that the solution to the Schrodinger Equation describes a decay function whose value doesn't quite get to zero before the other side of the barrier.  Sadly, there isn't an intuitive explanation; QM is just weird.  As Feynman says: "I think I can safely say that nobody understands quantum mechanics."

@djmips not really, a physical barrier is due to the repulsion of the electrons in a material, which can be overcome only by counteracting the repulsive force with a greater force, i.e gravity such as when a star collapses to form a neutron star. any physical barrier is due to electron repulsion,due to the Pauli exclusion principle which forbids any 2 electrons with the same spin from occupying the same energy state; electrons can't simply tunnel across this barrier because its a fundamental law
